identity.biochemicalTests: Gram-negative coccobacillus, fastidious, requires specialized media (e.g., Regan-Lowe or Bordet-Gengou), slow-growing ('mercury drop' colonies), strictly aerobic, oxidase +, urease â€“, non-motile.

clinicalProfile.summary: Bordetella pertussis causes pertussis (whooping cough) and occasionally pneumonia.

stagesOfIllness.details: Antibacterial treatment effective at this stage.
After 2 weeks of cough, hard to demonstrate any benefit of antibacterial treatment.
Treatment at late stages is used to eradicate the organism from the nose and prevent disease transmission.

prognosisNotes: Complications include: apnea, bradycardia, pulmonary hypertension, pneumonia, seizures, death (~ 1% mortality in young infants <2 months)
Lymphocytosis is associated with severe outcomes including pulmonary hypertension, respiratory failure and death in young infants

methods.details: Bronchial secretions for PCR or culture on special media.

generalNotes: Antibacterial treatment recommended if within 3-4 weeks of cough onset in older children and adults. Treat infants for up to 6 weeks after cough onset since shedding may persist

Recommend no antibiotic therapy if onset of cough more than 3 weeks ago. Exceptions: Near term pregnancy with cough onset within 6 weeks to prevent transmission to neonate; Up to 6 weeks after cough onset for persons with asthma, COPD, age > 65 yrs, or other immunocompromising conditions

drugs.dose: 500 mg po x 1, then 250 mg po once daily x 4 days
500 mg po bid x 7 days (or 1 gm/day po in two divided doses x 7 days)
10 mg/kg/day po on day 1 and then 5 mg/kg once daily on days 2 through 5 (maximum 500 mg/250 mg day)
15 mg/kg/day po in 2 divided doses x 7 days
8 mg/kg/day po in 2 divided doses x 14 days

drugs.comments: there is a small risk of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis associated with Azithromycin in infants less than 1 month old.

preventionAndScreening.details: Post exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is recommended for household contacts and others with close contacts such as children in daycare, health care personnel who have been exposed and are likely to expose high risk patients (neonates, pregnant patients). PEP is recommended for these groups regardless of vaccination history. Prophylactic drugs and doses are the same as for treatment.
See Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis, Vaccines. Non-immunized exposed persons should receive appropriate pertussis containing vaccines as soon as possible

drugSpecificPearls.pearl: Preferred agent due to shorter duration of therapy, less frequent dosing, and better side effects profile.
More GI side effects with Clarithromycin than Azithromycin
An alternative for persons older than 2 months who cannot tolerate Azithromycin or Clarithromycin or are infected with a macrolide-resistant strain
Active in vitro but clinical efficacy unknown.
